ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to apply computational models and methods to psychology data in MATLAB, as well as how to design and run a psychology experiment.

I learned how to create graphs in MATLAB given a real dataset, how to evaluate computational models given BIC and pseudo-r2, how to implement and launch an experiment on Prolific/Gorilla, how to discuss the model fits and where it's falling short, how to come up with a novel research question and write a final research paper given statistical analyses.
Better understanding of some theories of human psychology as well as how to carry out experiments and analyze data resulting from them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was interactive, and the curriculum and lectures were clear and intuitive. Sometimes, I felt like the content could have been a bit more rigorous or mathematically/statistically motivated.

Strengths: had a very clear flow of course material that was built on the homework, which made the homework feel relevant and necessary
Weaknesses: expected a great amount of work in the last 2-3 weeks with the final project without much preparation on how to begin to answer a novel question, how to find computational models given existing literature and how to implement those equations into code, or how to write a final research paper

Strengths: great psets, very thoughtful and helpful professor & TA. Interesting material. Weaknesses: the 2 hr class time chunk is pretty long and perhaps could've been used a little more effectively--personally I think it would've been nice to spend more time on the theories and a little less on code / specific aspects of the psets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes it's useful to learn MATLAB and basic statistics/psyc techniques, but beware it can eat up a lot of time on Wednesdays and Thursdays due to the pset schedule

If you are looking to go into computational modeling and want a very hands-on course that forces you to understand it to the degree of implementing it into a project yourself for further research, I would highly recommend taking this course. It is a big grind for an undergrad, even one who has done general research, especially at the end. However, if you have coding experience and can dedicate 6-8 hours across your Wed/Thur, the psets are very manageable. You learn a lot from this course, as it's a graduate level course, and leave feeling really accomplished at the end!

Yes, great course! Professor and TA are thoughtful and smart. Psets are difficult but worthwhile--always interesting and analytical. Pretty heavy workload but not bad if you're used to CS courses. Would recommend for S&DS / CPSC majors interested in psychology -- as someone kind of between those two majors, this class was totally worth. Great way to apply stats knowledge to an interesting application and learn matlab (surprisingly, a pretty intuitive and useful language)
